subject: Add schema validation to fix v2 code error returns
commit_message:
Add schema validation to fix v2 code error returns

For now, if user sends a bad request, v2 API returns unreasonable
code error message. This is unfriendly to end users.

For example, the curl request of a POST request with an empty body
$ curl -H "X-Auth-Token:$TOKEN" -X POST localhost:35357/v2.0/users
  -H 'Content-Type:application/json' -d '{}'

produces this return message:
{"error": {"message": "create_user() takes exactly 3 arguments
(2 given)", "code": 400, "title": "Bad Request"}}

After patch, new return message is:
{"error": {"message": "Expecting to find user in request body -
the server could not comply with the request since it is either
malformed or otherwise incorrect. The client is assumed to be in
error.", "code": 400, "title": "Bad Request"}}

This new return message matches what is on v3.
The patch fixes this by adding schema validation to v2.
For now, API schema validation is only on v3.

This can help improve end user experience.

Closes-Bug: #1455298

subject: HyperV: Fix vm disk path issue
commit_message:
HyperV: Fix vm disk path issue

As the disk number of iSCSI attached disks can change after host
reboot, passthrough attached volumes can get attached in this case.

This bug was partially fixed during Icehouse by this patch:
https://review.openstack.org/95356

One of the issues with this patch is that it only handles SCSI
attached disks, for which reason this issue continues to occur when
having generation 1 VMs booted from volume, in which case the disk
will be placed on the IDE controller.

In this case, one instance may end up booting from another tenant's
volume, which is a critical security issue.

Also, it assumes that the block device info volume order matches
the according disk controller slot order, which is wrong.

This patch fixes this issue, looping through the block device
info and fixing the disk path for all the passthrough attached
disks, regardless of the disk controller.

This requires the virtual disk resources attached to the instance
to be tagged with the serial number.

Note that some unit tests have been updated to match the ones from
Nova.

subject: libvirt: Force iSCSI disconnect after timeout
commit_message:
libvirt: Force iSCSI disconnect after timeout

Due to the async nature of Libvirt detachDeviceFlags[1] call, nova
libvirt driver shouldn't simply assume device detach always succeeds
when detachDeviceFlags() returns. Instead, it needs to check the domain
XML to verify if the device is really detached or not.

This change added a `libvirt_wait_detach_volume_seconds` option,
so that after this timeout value, libvirt volume driver will try to
force disconnect the volume.

This change depends on os-brick change:
  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/217032/

[1] http://libvirt.org/html/libvirt-libvirt-domain.html#virDomainDetachDeviceFlags

DocImpact
"wait_detach_volume_seconds" config option is added to allow deployer
to control number of seconds Nova waits for volume to be detached
from VM after libvirt issues detachDeviceFlag() call.  When times
out, Nova would force disconnect volume.

subject: Re-enable -1 child limits for nested quotas
commit_message:
Re-enable -1 child limits for nested quotas

Add back support for -1 limits of child projects. The way that we
support the -1 child limits requires the following changes:
  * Continue quota validation up the hierarchy if the current limit is
    -1 until we hit a hard limit or no more parents, and update the
    any relevant parents' allocated value along the way
  * When updating limits, special care needs to be taken when updating
    child limit to be -1, or when changing from a -1 limit
  * Enable support for creating reservations for "allocated" values
    to support the scenario that:
      - a volume is created on a project with a limit of -1
      - the parent's allocated value has been updated appropriately
      - the volume create fails and the child's in_use quota rolls back
      - now we must also rollback the parent's allocated value

NOTE: There is a race condition between validation the NestedQuotas
and when the driver may be switched into use, and if -1 quotas are used
the validation could be out of date. Will look into better support for
switching on of NestedQuotas on live deployment with -1 limits, which
would likely leverage the "allocated" reservation system.

subject: Also reset swift service object at upload time
commit_message:
Also reset swift service object at upload time

When you follow through swiftclient.service.SwiftService() it ends up
creating a swift swiftclient.connection.Connection() object within it
[1].

As noted in change Ib35dd49627bc2209060848e719e3cec40dbb4f2a ; the
swift client object does not support keystone sessions, so does not
handle having an expired token (tokens for RAX, the cloud we see this
issue with in nodepool, expire after 24 hours).

This leads to a very confusing exception about "No tenant specified"
[2] which I believe is actually somewhat of a red-herring; what has
happened is that the authentication failed, the client inside the
SwiftService object doing the upload hits its retry path and we end an
authentication failure path [3] that outputs this message.

The split between what happens in a swiftclient Connection() object
versus a SwiftService() object further suggests this is the failure
point -- you use the client object to do things list
list/create/delete containers, but the SwiftService object provides
the wrappers that handle the actual upload of the objects.  This
explains why we see the exception raised in the upload image path, but
not the creation of the containers to hold the image.

As with the swift client issue, the simplest way around this is to
always request a new SwiftService object when uploading a new image.

[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/python-swiftclient/tree/swiftclient/service.py#n226
[2] http://paste.openstack.org/show/488685/
[3] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/python-swiftclient/tree/swiftclient/client.py#n1544

Change-Id: I1c9d71ec828eb7d67045fb6bef468dc20e67292b

subject: Fix deleting containers behavior when half of container servers downed
commit_message:
Fix deleting containers behavior when half of container servers downed

A request for deleting container comes when container servers downed.
The request is handled by hand-off container servers but there is no
db in the servers so the request gets 404.

If number of replicas is even number (more than three) and half of
container servers downed, new requests for deleting container are NOT
success. The internal statuses are 204 and 404 so the response code
will be 503.

This patch overrides 404 status in the case 204 so new requests for
deleting container will be succeeded.

Swift recommends number of replicas is odd number but some deployers
use even number because of combination with SDS products.

Change-Id: Ibb217f752ddaf64602a73911a139f78090a9d1cc

subject: Fix posting containers behavior when half of container servers downed
commit_message:

Container servers downed when a request for posting container comes.
The request is handled with a hand-off container server but there is
no targeted container in the server (because it's a hand-off) so the
hand-off container server responded 404.

If number of replicas is even number (more than three) and half of
container servers downed, new requests for posting container NOT
success (but container meta will be replicated). The internal statuses
are 204 and 404 so the response code will be 503.

This patch overrides 404 status in the case with 204 so new requests
for posting container will be succeeded.

use even number because of combination with SDS products.

subject: Use new inventory schema in compute_node_get_all()
commit_message:
Use new inventory schema in compute_node_get_all()

In order to allow the scheduler to continue to function exactly the same
as it currently does during the time period while we migrate the data
and schema from the legacy layout to the resource-providers database
schema, we need to ensure that the
nova.db.sqlalchemy.api.compute_node_get_all() method returns all the
existing fields that may store capacity and usage information in the
compute_nodes table *but also* have the method return capacity and usage
information from the new inventories and allocations tables.

This patch adds some fairly complex SQLAlchemy-fu to the
compute_node_get_all() method, joining the compute_nodes table to the
new inventories and allocations tables for the three primary resource
classes currently stored in the compute_nodes table. For RAM, vCPU and
local disk resources, there are additional fields in the returned
results that correspond to the capacity and usage information stored in
the new inventories and allocations table.

For the RAM resource, the following fields are returned:

 * memory_mb <-- legacy compute_nodes.memory_mb field
 * memory_mb_used <-- legacy compute_nodes.memory_mb_used field
 * ram_allocation_ratio <-- legacy compute_nodes.ram_allocation_field
 * inv_memory_mb <-- new inventories.total field value for the MEMORY_MB
   resource class for that compute node
 * inv_memory_mb_reserved <-- new inventories.reserved field value for
   the MEMORY_MB resource class
 * inv_memory_mb_used <-- SUM() of the allocations.used field values for
   the MEMORY_MB resource class for that compute node

Similar fields for vCPU and local disk are returned for those resource
classes.

All of the inv_XXX fields are None if the inventory for the compute node
has not been migrated from the compute_nodes table to the inventories
table. In this way, the data migration on the ComputeNode object now has
the ability to tell if a compute node has had its inventory and usage
information migrated to the new resource-providers schema.

When changing the software_config_transport for an existing server,
os-collect-config will continue using the data from the old transport
which will become increasingly stale and will sometimes mask values from
the new transport.

The default list of collectors in os-collect-config is:
heat_local, ec2, cfn, heat, request, local, zaqar

This change explicitly enables these collectors:
ec2, <current transport>, local

``ec2`` is the nova metadata service, so should always be enabled.

``local`` allows local file overrides - this is generally unused but is
enabled for users who choose to use it for additional config data, or to
override the heat provided data.

``heat_local`` is only used on the first run of an unconfigured
os-collect-config for bootstrapping its own config file, so it can and

commit_message:
Add RPC handler for security group

To support cross-pod security group, we need to divide rule with
remote_group_id into rules with remote_ip_prefix since security
group id can not cross pods, so we add the following RPC handlers
to support.

(1) Given a port, find the security gruop rules associated with

access the port. This is already implemented in Neutron plugin so
we just inherit the proper base class.

group as the remote group. So when a port is added, we can update

subject: Raise AttributeError instead of NotImplementedError
commit_message:
Raise AttributeError instead of NotImplementedError

hasattr() will use object's getter to determine if a attr exists.
In python3, only AttributeError is checked:
https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#hasattr
If we raise other exception like NotImplementedError, the program
will exit due to the exception.

In python2, any exception is ok, so change to AttributeError will
make no regressions on python2.7.
https://docs.python.org/2/library/functions.html#hasattr

Magnum uses oslo_versionedobjects as it's base object, and it will
rely on the hasattr() to generate object attr dict. Before this patch
we got error when trying to generate object dict on python34 test:
'    _("Cannot load \'%s\' in the base class") % attrname)'
"NotImplementedError: Cannot load 'id' in the base class
http://logs.openstack.org/93/285693/3/check/gate-magnum-python34/960581a/console.html
Tha patch fix the problem.

Closes-Bug: #1551394

subject: Add libvirt-python to test-requirements.txt to enforce min version
commit_message:
Add libvirt-python to test-requirements.txt to enforce min version

libvirt-python should not be used in the unit tests, fakelibvirt should
be used to avoid test differences depending on the version of
libvirt-python in tox.

However, libvirt-python is required if you're running nova-compute with
the libvirt driver so we should list libvirt-python in
test-requirements.txt as an optional dependency (like oslo.vmware for
the vmware driver).

With this we can pin the minimum required version to 1.2.5 which allows
us to also remove a workaround for libvirt-python < 1.1.2 for
baselineCPU().

Since the driver, host and firewall modules all import libvirt we make
sure the tests using those modules are overwriting their global libvirt
attribute with fakelibvirt for consistent test results.

Change-Id: I22fc334884a90f3331a3fa040e6a0c952f0d7306

subject: Split instance resize operation into 2 phases
commit_message:
Split instance resize operation into 2 phases

Resize operation call compute.manager. Using cast
doesn't allow to notify user that something has
gone wrong. For example, an attempt to resize an instance down
fails silently. The error may only be found in the nova-compute
log file.

In order to return more useful error messages to the end user,
and to allow the operator to better diagnose failures, the resize
operation has been split into two parts. The first part checks
that the instance can indeed be resized, while the second part
performs the actual instance resize operation. The actual resize
operation is performed asynchronously, since the operation can
take a long time, however, the check operation is performed
synchronously, in order to provide better and quicker failure
conditions to the user.

Closes-bug: #1455460
